oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vietnamese civilian that worked on Vung Chua Mountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An older Vietnamese man in a military boonie hat and black jacket who worked on the signal base on Vung Chua Mountain, probably as a grass-cutter. He wears a white shirt under his jacket and is smiling.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Men; Military facilities; Hats
Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Qui Nhon (Vietnam)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ammons stated that many of the civilians from nearby Qui Nhon assisted in the maintenance of the base on Vung Chua Mountain. Men, like the individual pictured, typically cut the grass and maintained the grounds; many women polished boots and cleaned the floors at the base.
